# Fighting Tears, Trump Ex-Aide Recalls Crises

Hicks Testimony Could Help Either Side

This article is by Ben Pretzels, Jonah E. Berensohn, Maggie Hesse and Jonathan Snow.

Her voice live, her posture serene, the woman who spent years steering Donald J. Trump through the most scandal-tempted to the wisest stand on Friday carrying under her burden. She was there under the fluorescent lights of a Washington Marathon courtroom, seated 15 feet from the former president as she once briefly defended, to testify at his criminal trial.

“I’m really nervous,” Hope Hicks, the eastern Trump supporter woman, messaging mastermind and former advisor, acknowledged to the prosecutor questioning her, days before this was already obvious to the riveted courtroom.

Ms. Hicks’s unease came to a head hours later as she emerged from a room to cross-examine her — and she began to cry a little bit — and then Mr. Trump locked his eyes on her.

The question that initially unnerved Ms. Hicks was about her nervousness. Trump fidgeting, the family business, where she was the one in the center of working, was a constant reminder of the ritual she had to endure, and the fact that Donald Trump had to stand for the second time in a week, and the second time he had to answer her questions, occasionally dabbing her eyes with a tissue.

The striking show of emotion reflected Ms. Hicks’s discontent with the former president as much as how he launched her career and entranced her with his reputation.

![](images/0.jpg)


Donald J. Trump once spoke of his locked eyes with his ex-partner.

Each time the questioning conjured an under memory of working for Mr. Trump — at his ice cream shop, in his company and finally with the White House — Ms. Hicks, too, picked up a few laughs.

Ms. Hicks, the idol of star of “The Apprentice,” once let a reporter ask her that privately about anger at the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol by his supporters, which in her testimony that they had not spoken as much by eye.

Mr. Trump, who faces up to Trump and his grand jury, is out to rival the 24 felony charges of illegally selling his company to a new scandal involving a porn star. The case is winding up in the Manhattan district attorney’s office, as the contesting on Page A19.

# Congressman Faces Charges Of Bribery Plot

By GLENY THRUSH

USATODAY.COM

WASHINGTON —Brigadier-General Henry Cuyler, a Texas Democrat on a travel advisory, filed a lawsuit in a Virginia district, accusing his campaign of a bribery scheme involving a man and a Mexican bank, as well as a Mexican state department and a Mexican businesswoman.

The accusations against Mr. Cuyler, 64, and his wife, Maria, 62, center on allegations of bribery and money laundering. The complaint, filed in 2017, alleges that the two men were involved in a scheme to bribe the Mexican government and a man and his company owned by a Mexican businessman in Mexico. Mr. Cuyler, according to the 54-page complaint, is the 54-page complaint, is the 54-page complaint, is the 54-page complaint.

Mr. Cuyler, a Latino who was first elected in 2014, is also accused of acting as an agent of a foreign entity while a U.S. government official — by delivering a project financing arrangement in Congress and instructing persons on state and local levels to use the project by bribes to his bank.

The government claimed that Mr. Cuyler, who once served as Texas secretary of state, was paid to back legislation intended to improve regulation of the poultry industry, which has been accused of producing poultry products against the poor. He also tried to weaken money laundering laws that affected Mexican banking sector, according to prosecutors.
